2.32 p.m.

    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [Allotted day].

    Head 33-

    

    The Chairman (Dr Fong Kim Heng): Second Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1963 as contained in Paper Cmd. 29 of 1963. We will now deal with the heads of expenditure in

Column: 728

respect of which amendments stand in the Order Paper. Head 33 - Ministry of Finance.

    Mr Chio Cheng Thun (Choa Chu Kang)(In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to he allocated for Head 33 be reduced by the whole sum in respect of subhead 34.

    I would like to ask the Minister for Finance this. In 1963 there was a provision of $30 million. I do not know why there is a need for a further provision of $200 million in these present Estimates. I would also like to know what is the purpose of this $200 million. Also, to what extent has the present amount already been used by the Government?

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Member has asked for information as to why it is necessary to transfer this large sum of money from the Consolidated Fund to the Development Fund. This is a fairly reasonable request for information, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir. So I shall try to enlighten him. There are two main funds operated by the Government. The first is the Consolidated Fund. This is the Fund in which all revenues of the State are kept. From this Consolidated Fund all payments of Government Departments are paid out: running of Ministries, for staff, public services, and all the other items of expenditure in the Main Estimates which we passed the day before yesterday. That is the Consolidated Fund. In other words, it is a fund which deals with the operating expenses of the Government and keeps the current revenues of the Government. In other words, it is our current account.

    The other fund is the Development Fund. All the projects for capital expenditure, such as the Development Estimates which this Assembly passed yesterday, are paid out of monies of the Development Fund. The Development Fund gets its income from three principal sources. The first is loans which we raise each year in Singapore. The second is the interest on the earnings of the Development Fund. The third source comes from allocations from the Consolidated Fund to the Development

Column: 729

Fund. As Members will know, each year sums of money are transferred from the Consolidated Fund to the Development Fund. The purpose of this item in the Supplementary Estimates is to transfer this amount of money, namely, $200 million, from the Consolidated Fund to the Development Fund to meet expenditures in the State's development plan. So the short answer as to what the money is going to be used for is that it will be used to pay for expenditure on the projects which this Assembly approved yesterday.

    Now, why is it $200 million? If the Member will read the notes attached to this subhead, he will find this in the last sentence: "The Consolidated Fund now stands at $288 million which is much in excess of normal requirements...." Normally we want something like $60 million in the Consolidated Fund. That is quite ample to meet Government's expenditure in its day-to-day operations. But the Consolidated Fund has stood at this very large figure as a result of surpluses accumulated in previous years. It is necessary to transfer these surpluses in a lump sum now. Members will recollect that in 1961, we made a transfer of $80 million. Today, with a transfer of $200 million, we will have transferred $280 million of previous years' surpluses into the Development Fund. In 1959 we transferred $20 million from the Consolidated Fund to the Development Fund, and from 1960 to 1963 in each year we transferred $30 million. So the total of all these monies transferred from the Consolidated Fund to the Development Fund stands at something like $420 million. This is the surplus which we have referred to every now and then. Obviously there is no point in letting the money remain in the Consolidated Fund. In fact, the Barisan Sosialis have always asked in the previous Assembly why we do not spend this money. Now when we are transferring this money to the Development Fund, they say, "Why do you want to do this?" They cannot have it both ways. I hope I have explained the matter clearly to the Member for Choa Chu Kang. He was urging me yesterday to spend this money. This exercise, among other things, will have the effect of obliging him. I hope I have made the

Column: 730

position clear. There is no catch in it. I can see him frowning. His brain is physically working! But if it is still not clear to him, I will be only too happy to explain further the working of this financial arrangement.

    Mr Chio Cheng Thun(In Mandarin): If $200 million is to be allocated to the Development Fund, I would like to know how much of it has already been used, and to what purpose.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Since the money has not been transferred to the Development Fund, obviously we cannot use it. You have got to put the money into the Development Fund before you can touch it. So the answer is that none of it has so far been used.

    The Member has asked, "How will it be used?" Only yesterday we had a long and sometimes acrimonious debate on how to spend money on development. This money is to meet the expenditure which this House approved yesterday. I hope I have made myself clear. But he looks puzzled. Perhaps if he wants further clarification, I am prepared to go outside the Chamber, get down with a pencil and paper, and make everything more crystal clear than could possibly be the case when one talks to each other across the Table.

    The Chairman (Dr Fong Kim Heng): Does the Member for Choa Chu Kang wish to withdraw the amendment?

    Mr Chio Cheng Thun: Yes.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $200,000,000 for Head 33 ordered to stand part of the Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1963.

2.45 p.m.

    Head 36-

    Mr Koo Young (Thomson)(In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 36 be reduced by the whole sum in respect of subhead 62.

    A sum of $450,000 is now being asked for additional expenditure on the National Theatre. We heard that the theatre opened on 31st August this year

Column: 731

when the South-East Asia Cultural Festival was held. How is it that there is a further need of $450,000? Does it mean that this money will be spent on neon lights and decorations of P.A.P. signs?

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I am indeed surprised at the question asked by the Member for Thomson. It is unusually short. It is customary for the Barisan and the pro-Communist boys to be very interested in cultural activities. They consider it a means to disseminate Communist propaganda and to indoctrinate the young.

    Sir, the National Theatre project was approved at a total cost of $2.2 million. The cost was worked out by the architects as well as the former Director of Public Works. Government's contribution is the balance between the total cost of $2.2 million and the total sum of donations including interest derived thereon. The total amount of donations, inclusive of interest, if the Opposition Member is interested to know, is $856,279.04 as at 16th December, 1963.

    The Member for Thomson has touched on the delay of construction of this National Theatre. We have to appreciate the following facts. Piling work on the National Theatre was completed in October last year. Work on the building contract commenced on 24th October, 1962. The original target date for the completion was 31st May, 1963, which meant that the steel contractor had to finish the steel work by 15th May, 1963. The technical difficulties involved in the steel work prevented the target date from being met.

    Sir, there is another reason for the delay. The late completion of the level structural drawings was due, in a large measure, to the necessity of making careful calculations to ensure a safer cantilever. It should be noted that the contractor's efforts to complete the work quickly are reflected in the fact that during the period 23rd October, 1962, to 7th August, 1963, the building contractor spent approximately $118,000 by way of overtime wages. And also during

Column: 732

the period 7th March, 1963, to 20th July, 1963, the steel contractor spent approximately $38,000 by way of overtime wages. The work had to be rushed as it was necessary to have the main building and stage roof ready before the South-East Asia Cultural Festival in which the Member for Thomson is so interested. I shall enlighten him on this later on.

    The Festival was held from 8th August, 1963, to 15th August, 1963. All this work for the Cultural Festival was completed in time.

    Sir, it should also be noted that the National Theatre is architecturally unique in South-East Asia, perhaps in the whole of Asia. Nowhere in Asia can we find a cantilever thrust jutting out 150 feet without any supporting columns. In a project of this nature, undue speed in construction is not desirable. In fact, it is dangerous.

    Sir, the Assembly is now requested to pass this further contribution of $450,000 made to the National Theatre Trust. We recall that on 24th July, 1963, the previous Assembly passed a first contribution of $500,000 to the National Theatre Trust. This request, therefore, is the second payment.

    The Member should also note that a further payment will have to be made in accordance with what has been agreed in respect of Government's contribution to the Trust as mentioned earlier.

    Sir, for the information of this Assembly, the National Theatre Trust was established by an Ordinance No. 61 of 1961 on 19th November, 1960. The Chairman of the Trust is Mr Lee Khoon Choy. The other members are Inche Zubir Said, Mr Ng Aik Huan, Mr Paul Abisheganaden, Madam Liu Hsue Ying, Mr K. P. Bhaskar, Mr Liao Sung Yang, Mr Liew Yung Ho, Mr Wee Kim Wee, Mr Ang Hock Lam, and the Permanent Secretary to the Minister for Culture. All these are voluntary members. The object of the Board is to manage, on behalf of the Minister for Culture, the National Theatre and other theatrical institutions placed under its management by the Minister.

Column: 733



    The Member for Thomson probably would be interested to know something about our South-East Asia Cultural Festival, which I earlier promised to enlighten. Sir, the first South-East Asia Cultural Festival which we in Singapore had the distinction of staging took place from 8th August, 1963, to 15th August, 1963. It cost the Government about $311,500. This is only a provisional figure as the accounts have not yet been finalised, but it is more or less accurate. The gate receipts amounted to $52,671.03, of which $45,220.83 was collected at the National Theatre and $7,450.20 was collected at the Victoria Theatre. The net cost to Government was, therefore, approximately $258,829. The gate receipts would have been much more but for the complimentary tickets issued to the artistes and other guests of participant countries. The tickets were sold at $5, $3, $2, and $1 at the National Theatre and $3 and $1 at the Victoria Theatre. The participating member-countries were Cambodia, the Federation of Malaya, Hong Kong, India, Laos, Pakistan, the Philippines, Sabah, Singapore, South Vietnam, and Thailand.

    I think the Member for Thomson may be interested to know that his former colleague or former adviser, the former strong man in the S.A.T.U. group, the pro-Communist group of unions, was one of the keen supporters of the National Theatre. He contributed a lot to the National Theatre.

    Sir, the National Theatre was intended to be a small one, but because of the tremendous enthusiasm shown by the donors and well-wishers, we had to reconsider our plan. The structures have to be reconsidered and our National Theatre is now a sizable one. I can promise the Member for Thomson that it will not be used for staging any songs which they are now teaching the small children in the kindergarten classes in the rural areas.

    Mr Koo Young(In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, we all know that the National Theatre was opened on the 31st August this year. Yet the Parliamentary

Column: 734

Secretary has said that it has not yet been completed. He has also referred to the Communist activities and Barisan disturbances. I expect him to talk in such a trend - accusing the Communists of interfering with the work so that the Theatre could not be completed in time. But fortunately he did not talk in this manner.

    The Chairman (Dr Fong Kim Heng): Order. The Member should refrain from crude and unparliamentary language. Please proceed.

    Mr Koo Young(In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, it is only meant to describe him adjectivally. But since you have ruled it as improper, I withdraw.

3.00 p.m.

    They claim that the Theatre is the most beautiful and the grandest in the whole of South-East Asia. We would like to ask whether the Government have been misusing public funds by allocating a further provision of $450,000. The National Theatre may appear to be grand and beautiful on the outside, but it may not be so in actual fact. If you put some zinc sheets and have them painted, they too can appear to be pretty from the outside. But what we want is something concrete, real, and valuable and not something that is beautiful superficially. Perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary has been travelling all over South-East Asia. That is why he finds the National Theatre in Singapore to be the most beautiful in the whole of this region.

    Apart from the provision of $450,000, the sum of $2.2 million has already been used on the National Theatre. Has it not been a waste? Perhaps you can say the National Theatre appears superficially to be very beautiful. But it might be too extravagant an item of expenditure to spend $2.2 million just on this sort of National Theatre. What we want is not the most beautiful National Theatre in South-East Asia, but something that is of practical use and value to the people. Moreover, we would like to know whether there has been any waste or misuse of public money. It might be possible that because the Ministry of

Column: 735

Culture wanted to meet the completion date of the National Theatre, a certain wastage of money or some irregularities might have taken place. We do not know. Perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary concerned can enlighten us on this, instead of talking about Communists.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee(In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I would like to clarify certain points. The Member for Thomson has said the Government wasted this money, which was public money. We used the money to build the National Theatre. The money, of course, came from the people. But it is for the good of the people. How can he say that this is a waste of money when we are not using it for ourselves? The National Theatre has been built from the contributions of members of the public. Whenever there is a $100 donation, we too contribute an agreed amount at the ratio of 1:1. So how can he say that this is a waste? The building of the National Theatre has been initiated by the public themselves, and for their own use. From what the Member for Thomson has mentioned just now, it appears that he might be qualified to be an associate member of the Architects Association of Singapore. He talks about whether the National Theatre was a waste or not and whether it was beautiful or not from the outside. He makes all these comments as though he was a qualified architect. I think the Member for Jalan Kayu is more concerned with the style and structure of pig sties and chicken sheds. He might well be conversant with this subject. But he and the people over the other side might not be so well conversant with the true architecture of the National Theatre. They are not experts in this field.

    The National Theatre is a very big construction job and much effort has been put in to build it. So all sorts of details must be taken into consideration. The second reason for the delay in the completion of the National Theatre is that the public's enthusiasm and zeal has made it possible for the original plan to be modified and altered.

Column: 736



    Just now the Member for Thomson has asked whether the National Theatre would be safe or would it collapse. I can assure him that if he were to go and look at the National Theatre, the ceiling would not collapse on his head.

    About the possible malpractices committed by the contractor, the Government are very cautious about this and pay very much attention to it. If he is interested, I will ask the P.W.D. engineer to accompany him to the work site to inspect the construction work. He can see whether there have been malpractices committed by the contractor.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, in the past few days, the Barisan Sosialis Members have been always finding fault with every plan and suggestion made by the Government. Their motive and objectives are to sabotage and not to make any constructive criticism.

    For example, the Member for Thomson has criticised the construction work of the National Theatre. He has also accused us of having misused the $2.2 million. We know that the National Theatre building campaign was launched in 1959 during Loyalty Week and that it received the enthusiasm and support of the public. Even the Barisan Sosialis and the S.A.T.U. unions also gave enthusiatic support to it. This National Theatre has a very great historical significance to the people of Singapore. In the past, the colonial regime was never able to put up such a theatre. If the Barisan Sosialis had been elected to power, they too would not have been able to put up such a theatre. But today when the people are awakening to political consciousness, the Barisan Sosialis will never be in a position to come to power. The National Theatre will be able to fuse the cultures of the various races in Malaysia. Those who have come to Singapore from abroad will know that the National Theatre plays a very important role in creating a Malaysian culture.

    Mr Koo Young(In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I did not intend to speak further on this. But perhaps they have not been listening to what I have

Column: 737

said. They were dreaming. They were shouting anti-Communist slogans.

    I was merely asking whether there has been a waste of money in building this National Theatre. It does not mean that I am opposed to the building of this National Theatre. What I want to know is: in the course of construction was there any waste in order to speed up and have it completed on the 31st August?

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Kim San): No.

    Mr Koo Young(In Mandarin): Therefore, they should have round-the-clock work. Were there any malpractices or irregularities during the course of construction? That is what I want to know.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: For a stupid question there is always a stupid answer. The Member did not know what he was asking for. If he is interested to know whether the Government are throwing money away, the answer is simple - N-o- no. Sir, we are not the kind of government that throw our money away by putting it in an unprofitable investment. We calculate and consider every item of expenditure and we cut the expenditure to the bone. There is no waste. The answer is no. It is simple. I think what the Barisan Members are really sore at is that they cannot turn the National Theatre into a red star theatre, where they can have Communist culture, the harvest dance, very inspiring songs from China, probably some songs from Indonesia and some inspiration from Aidit of Indonesia. I think this is what the Barisan Sosialis Members are sore at with this National Theatre. Because they know that they cannot make use of the National Theatre for their own purpose.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I think I can give a straightforward answer to the question posed by the Member for Thomson. Though I am not connected with the building of the National Theatre, I will try to answer his question. He asks whether there has been wastage in public and Government funds in the building of the National Theatre. The answer is no. He asks why

Column: 738

should there be work round the clock? The answer is probably this. In coming to a contractual agreement with the contractor, there is always a deadline and probably the contractor finds that he cannot make the deadline, therefore he has to do work round the clock.

    Another worry of his is, why should we spend more than $2 million on the National Theatre? Sir, in Singapore we build for a useful purpose; we build in order that it can be of practical use for our people. But, at the same time, we want to build and see that we should be proud of whatever we build. The National Theatre is something which one should be proud of, if one embarks on that venture. As a loyal citizen of this State and of Malaysia, I think one should be willing to spend a bit more money on a project like the National Theatre, so that we can embellish it a little bit more, have better fittings here and there, so that when visitors come to Singapore, we can say, "Look, this is our National Theatre. It is about the best in the Far East."

3.15 p.m.

    Mr Chia Thye Poh (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, when the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture and the Back-benchers talk about the National Theatre they raise the bogey of Communism. The P.A.P. are very anxious to make use of the National Theatre for their own party purposes and when we raise this question they become very sensitive.

    The building of the National Theatre is a good thing, more so because it has received the support of the people. But after its completion, will the Party in power - as they have stated - be able to promote Malaysian culture? [Interruption] During the last few years, the P.A.P. have monopolised the promotion of different cultures and they have banned the publication of cultural magazines which were opposed to them. Books that really reflect the people's consciousness in dances, poetry and songs have also been banned by the Government for their own party purposes. It is doubtful whether they are really able to foster Malayan culture. If they carry on in this way, Singapore

Column: 739

will become a cultural desert because the dances, poetry and songs which really reflect the people's way of life are discouraged and suppressed by the Government. Therefore, the standard of culture in Singapore cannot be raised any further. The building of a so-called new culture is another form of deception.

    We hope the P.A.P. will change their attitude of monopolising the promotion of culture and will really encourage the promotion of cultures which are beneficial to the people of Singapore and Malaya - cultures which truly represent the way of life of the people - and not encourage the promotion of foreign cultures such as American culture.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: I just do not understand why every time we talk about Communism, the Barisan stand up without hesitation to defend it. If they are not Communists, why do they defend it?

    Sir, as I have said, what really makes them feel sore is that they cannot make use of the National Theatre as they made use of the Dramatic Society in Nanyang University to disseminate Communist culture. But if we were to give them a chance to stage some dances of Mao Tse-tung and his gang or of Aidit, probably the Member for Jurong would agree and he would donate a few dollars.

    Sir, it is alleged that the National Theatre is intended to serve as a tool for the P.A.P. This is an utter insult not only to the people of Singapore who contributed so willingly towards the National Theatre fund but also to the countries which participated in the South-East Asia Festival - Cambodia, the Federation of Malaya, Hong Kong, India, Ceylon, Pakistan, the Philippines, Sabah, Singapore, South Vietnam and Thailand, not Jakarta and China.

    Sir, in the last few years, we have done much to promote Malaysian culture - may I emphasise, Malaysian culture - and I can assure the Members of the Barisan Sosialis that we have also done very, very much to curb Communist culture.

Column: 740



    On the question of publications that were banned from circulation, just give me a list of them that they consider are not Communist-inspired and I will produce them in this House and prove that they are Communist-inspired.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I would like to say a few more words. I was very pleased to hear a Member of the Barisan supporting certain projects like the National Theatre. I have two questions to ask him. First, why did he not say "Malaysian" culture but "Malayan" culture? Second, is it not a fact that Malaysian culture is now in existence? Its existence has been recognised even by Russia, though Indonesia still refuses to recognise it. On this question, I would like to ask him what types of songs and poetry really reflect the people's way of life. We say that this cannot be judged by a group of politicians but by the broad masses - by the majority of the people and not by a minority.

    Mr Chia Thye Poh(In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the last Member who spoke on this question did so in the hope that the reactionary groups in Malaya, the United Kingdom or in the United States of America might give him a title like "anti-Communist doctor or hero". Culture is a thing that belongs to the majority of the people and not only to the ruling class.

    As to what magazines, journals and literature have been banned, I believe the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture himself should know more about them. He cannot deceive the people. He can go through the records to find out the facts.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: I really do not know whether the Member for Sembawang will get a medal from the British or American imperialists, but I am confident that the Members of the Barisan Sosialis are going to get medals from Soekarno and Aidit for being their spokesmen in this House.

    Sir, I wish to answer the question on the banning of publications. We are confident that each and every one of those publications that we ban is not desirable, and that it is not in the

Column: 741

interest of the people of Singapore for these publications to be circulated. If the Member for Jurong is interested, I would like him to give me a list of the books, poems or songs which he thinks are good for the people of Singapore and then I will consider the matter. As far as we are concerned, all the books, poems and songs that we ban are not in the interest of the people of Singapore for them to be circulated.

    Mr Poh Ber Liak (Tampines)(In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, just now the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture has again raised the Communist bogey. I think it is better for him not to distort the facts. It he wants to debate Communism - he can do so outside the Assembly with anybody he likes. He should not repeatedly raise the Communist bogey in this Assembly. While we are discussing affairs concerning the people of Singapore, he introduces the Communist bogey again.

    Yesterday, the Minister for Culture asked us to deny whether we are Communists. I say that we do not oppose the banning of Communist literature. But can the P.A.P. say that the dances, literature, poems and songs that really reflect the way of life of the people of Singapore are Communist-inspired? Why were some of those people connected with them banished? The criterion on whether a song or literature is Communist- inspired or not depends on the judgment of the people and not on the decision of the P.A.P. oligarchy or by Mr Lee Khoon Choy alone.

    I would like to ask the ruling clique, how many publications and concert programmes have been banned?

    Inche Rahamat Bin Kenap (Geylang Serai)(In Malay): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Barisan Members accuse us of raising the Communist bogey on the National Theatre. If they are really not Communists, why do they not say "Malaysia" but "Malaya and Singapore"? If they consider themselves citizens of Malaysia but they refuse to say "Malaysia", it means that they are anti-Malaysia like Indonesia, which refuses to recognise the existence of

Column: 742
